@tikiblagojev Yes, a lot of it is just what makes sense for that person, and even if it makes less sense, if you have a support network for one language and not another, or a tutorial that makes more sense, that can be enough to swing it

@northernjamie Agreed. That's the reason I switched to R a few years ago. I'm now increasingly moving back to Python because of Colab notebooks in Google Drive but I find myself using both for different types of tasks.

@L_A_Kelly I thought that too but I have come across a few who learned R first and then felt Python was easier. Of course another hypothesis is that it was easier because they'd already started to think like a coder more
@lucastimmons I teach JS too - but from an industry POV it's not used for data analysis, more interactivity and vis (so it's not discussed in the context of finding stories)

@glynmottershead Makes sense - it's like teaching pandas rather than Python. But as a language the feedback I get is that Python just 'makes more sense' (e.g. for loops/if tests are more convoluted in R - and those horrible pipes)

There'll inevitably be some disagreement here, so here are mine: 
- Python is best for *beginner* coders to pick up IME. The whole %>% thing in R is a big turn-off for some
- Both have an active community - Python's is just more US-based https://t.co/fVouh4r2ZH https://t.co/IdCqXLO5XV
En espa√±ol: La pir√°mide invertida del periodismo de datos via https://t.co/nEgiGhHeJ1 (y tambien: https://t.co/9caRb07S1z) #ddj https://t.co/1BVcp5Pc54

@corinne_podger @MarcSettle And news days: we have a social/mobile community news day where they can only use social platforms, and the students plan a multiplatform news fortnight including platform-specific roles (more in this @BJTC_UK conference presentation from 2019 https://t.co/evBtpJLH7n)

@corinne_podger @MarcSettle The Narrative module is quite important as it's teaching adapting to new platforms, e.g. composition/the rule of thirds with vertical video; the importance of clear audio in social video; narrative structure in 280 characters/threads.

@BisianiSimona Oh, and one other pro for Python is that dataframe columns don't get coerced to a single object type like in R (i.e. if you have strings in your numerical column you don't lose them, or end up with numbers formatted as strings)

@BisianiSimona That's very useful. I swing between both R and Python (or SQL/command line etc) depending on the problem and any existing codebase I'm reusing or adapting. But I've noticed when teaching that people seem to find Python more intuitive
@MarcSettle It‚Äôs entry level so students will have some work experience but not necessarily anything multiplatform - modules at https://t.co/44mKqS5TaW

@DeBeaudoir @guardian Loving the fact you can search these CDP responses by the way! Shame it's not quite as open as their 'open data'. Some interesting questions in there - I see stuff about buying carbon credits for example

@DeBeaudoir @guardian Yes that does complicate it. Although revenue only measures money going through the company, before production costs. So I guess people not buying could still mean a drop in revenue figures, even if they continued to make stuff (but as you say, it may be delayed a little)

@DeBeaudoir @guardian I mean people buying less of the company's products, which would mean their revenue and their emissions both drop regardless of whether they're actually doing anything to reduce emissions (or LCAs).

@DeBeaudoir @guardian I can see this rating system is trying to have your cake and eat it - i.e. companies can continue to expand and use up more resources while appearing to generate lower emissions (when they are not, overall). 
It's just not factoring in revenue could be misleading too.

@DeBeaudoir @guardian A gross reduction could simply mean a company is producing fewer things, because people aren't buying them, though? It might be environmentally irresponsible, worse than its more successful competitors. (Not disagreeing with the overall need to reduce consumption)

@DeBeaudoir @guardian I agree it's an overall increase. I'm trying to work out what would be a fairer way of recognising emission reductions. If revenue wasn't factored in, would we end up with 'A-rated' companies who actually create more emissions per item?

@DeBeaudoir @guardian What I mean is: if a company's revenue doubles, you'd expect its emissions to double. And if its revenue drops by 50%, likewise. 
So if its revenue doubles, but its emissions increases by 10%, it would be fair to say the company is reducing its emissions per item

@DeBeaudoir @guardian Great idea to look at this. If they didn‚Äôt put emissions into the context of revenue (how much business that organisation is doing) wouldn‚Äôt you have companies looking good when they‚Äôre merely doing less business? (Instead of reducing emissions for each item made)

Some data journalism jobseeking advice: what he said üëá #ddj https://t.co/n2rYnj4PaL

"Rounding off a discussion is also more difficult in [remote interviews] because you cannot use body language as clearly on a screen." Their solution: "Use body language more actively and physically raising a hand, as a sign of wanting to stop the conversation." https://t.co/SipKYN3Rsd

...Body language is useful, it says. "For example, using thumbs up when you understand or think something is good. And of course, wave when you say hello and goodbye." https://t.co/ONZw4i24Pr #bcujournos https://t.co/LRGPIA3MyI

"It is an advantage for the interviewer to display active listening and enhance the dialogical communication by increasing bodily and facial expressions, e.g. smile more and preferably more exaggerated, and amplify nodding in the affirmative instead of saying "mmm" and "yes"."

The researchers advise prioritising looking at participants to notice feedback, rather than maintaining eye contact by looking at the camera (while also trying to look at the camera occasionally) https://t.co/ONZw4i24Pr #bcujournos https://t.co/IpdpiQ9cp5

"Extensively small talk with participants as they arrive and plan a simple icebreaker exercise," the research suggests. "The goal is not to find the most creative high-demand virtual icebreaker, but the one which will succeed in easing the tension and establishing proximity" https://t.co/yvGylIWeTq
...Next, tips on building rapport: exchange emails before the interview, they suggest. Try out the technology with the participant. https://t.co/T2GVAm4Klr #bcujournos https://t.co/dKU0qOe44M

...The research then gives some tips on setting. Their focus is on comfort and distraction ‚Äî but I'd also add that journalistic interviewers should be prepared to direct the interviewee for composition reasons, too (e.g. lighting, background, position etc) #bcujournos https://t.co/fJVH8lLjXx
...The first set of tips on remote interviewing are largely logistical and technical ‚Äî including having a back-up plan. https://t.co/qSXZ2sxqrI

Interesting research on using Zoom etc for interviewing: says biggest challenges are "building rapport and restricted visual cues, turn-taking, participant activation and participant validation". Offers tips! https://t.co/3QURoi0267 #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 @lukew_powell 35/ "Follow the NUJ and [IPSO] codes of conduct and practice which list what journalists should be doing in interviews," suggests @lukew_powell #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 @lukew_powell 34/ "To reduce your chances of being sued, or improve your chances of winning in court, persuade your interviewee to make a signed statement confirming what they say" ‚Äî Sally Adams, Interviewing for Journalists via @lukew_powell #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 @lukew_powell 33/ Check the cuttings on what you're told in the interview. Check the content with the interviewee ‚Äî @lukew_powell #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 32/ The final group of interviewing tips come from @lukew_powell  on law and ethics: keep any recordings and notes for 1 year after the story is published #bcujournos https://t.co/8xsKVsAyWf

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 31/ @joeavfc99's last tip on interviewing is: "Preparation builds a connection with the subject. It shows you've given them the respect of doing research into them beforehand" #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 30/ Engage with the subject - "elements such as eye contact and smiling will form a deeper connection with your interviewee" ‚Äî Sally Adams, Interviewing for Journalists (2009) via @joeavfc99
 #bcujournos https://t.co/awlcB3sgwE

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 29/ Find a definitive interviewing style, says @joeavfc99. For example, some journalists will pose longer and more heavily constructed questions in order to try to draw deeper answers #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ @joeavfc99 28/ "The good interviewer is faceless, egoless and devoid of personality" ‚Äî Sally Adams, Interviewing for Journalists (2009) via @joeavfc99 #bcujournos https://t.co/HjQrHOpWwZ

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ 27/ Now some tips from @joeavfc99 on celeb interviews: when making the initial approach "consider the way you come across. You want to present yourself and your publication in as favourable a way as possible"
#bcujournos https://t.co/hb5JmQ8odG

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ 26/ "A sympathetic, understanding response often produces a better result than direct questioning" ‚Äî @paramgarcha_ 
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ 25/ ü§ù"Establish a good relationship with your contacts," adds @paramgarcha_, "as it will allow them to trust you more" 
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ 24/ It's important to find out what's going on in your area, says @paramgarcha_: who's the largest local employer? What are the local concerns? #bcujournos
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 @paramgarcha_ 23/ Perception is important when it comes to interviewing, says @paramgarcha_ "Have a positive image of yourself." #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 22/ Next tips on interviewing from @paramgarcha_: "Have a restrained approach and don't attack the interviewee if they are lying"
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 21/ Ensure that an interview remains a dialogue, says @adamb__6 (no relation), and not just one person talking or asking questions. Let the interview flow. #bcujournos https://t.co/VrZKgj0dfQ

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 20/ Publishing an audio recording is often more useful for online interviews, says @adamb__6, as it avoids the cleaning task of writing an interview up (but it may not be as effective in terms of SEO)
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 19/ Focus on producing short, snappier interview content online, says @adamb__6 ‚Äî and consider producing short clips before you publish the full thing
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc @adamb__6 18/ "Avoid doing Q&As," is the next tip from @adamb__6 They can be considered lazy journalism. Ensure there is sufficient "colour and essence" #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc 17/ Moving on to tips for interviewing for the internet, via  @adamb__6: Use the 'sandwich technique': ask a nice question prior to a nasty question 
#bcujournos https://t.co/4VlbXZe3pp
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc 16/ Final tip from @harrygfc: "If the deadline is later, you can go back and type up your quotes with more context" #bcujournos https://t.co/am169BO6r7

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc 15/ "Make sure quotes are not libellous," is another tip from @harrygfc (or at least, if they are defamatory, make sure you can prove them to be true or draw on another legal defence)
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc 14/ Re-read your notes and check for any gaps that need to be filled, adds @harrygfc 
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens @harrygfc 13/ "If there are gaps in the interview, go back and contact your interviewee" says @harrygfc 
#bcujournos https://t.co/8lbsfVK924
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 12/ The next 5 tips are from @harrygfc ‚Äî first tip: If a deadline is immediate, the quotes should be written directly from the notes you took #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 11/ The last of @tom_keens's 5 interviewing tips is: "If it's not someone you're going to interview regularly, you can afford to annoy them, provoking some good quotes" https://t.co/HkC0QtrLLc
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 10/ "Pauses before delivering an answer can be an indicator of lying" ‚Äî @tom_keens #bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 9/ Lean towards the interviewee and they'll talk more, says @tom_keens 
#bcujournos
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 8/ "Feet are the hardest body part to control. If they start to tap or twitch, then the interviewee is uncomfortable" ‚Äî¬†@tom_keens #bcujournos https://t.co/pArOCQXqH8
@PardeepKalirai @tom_keens 7/ "...If they lean back and fold their arms something that's been said has caused this defensive change of mood" #bcujournos https://t.co/CoYPIgUO9f

@PardeepKalirai 6/ Next up with interviewing tips is @tom_keens: "A shift in posture is significant and worth taking note of, especially when the interviewee is leaning forward and talking freely..."
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai 5/ Best tip so far from @PardeepKalirai: if you can't get an interview, put yourself in the target's shoes and imagine what could persuade them to do the interview 
#bcujournos https://t.co/KpWQCAR9wb

@PardeepKalirai 4/ When interviewing, make sure to dress suitably to suit the occasion and publication you represent, says @PardeepKalirai 
#bcujournos

@PardeepKalirai 3/ Spend as much time as you can to research, prepare and plan the interview ‚Äî @PardeepKalirai 
#bcujournos https://t.co/ag2DR6kF9j
@PardeepKalirai 2/ "Stand out from other journalists - don't ask the same questions as it can bore the interviewee" #bcujournos
1/ "For the first question, ask a gentle, wise question as it allows them to collect their thoughts and get ready to answer," says @PardeepKalirai #bcujournos

ICYMI I spent this morning looking into the üí∞ of a celeb charity üåü #ddj #bcujournos https://t.co/XcBGImWoXL

18/ Thanks to @PeteWhite for pointing out that the Charity Commission interest in the charity pre-dates the Mail on Sunday article in May - with a compliance case in Sept 2020 mentioned in the press release https://t.co/l1HRz1glKM

RT @petewhite: @paulbradshaw I think the Charity Commission interest goes back longer.

The charity was previously the subject of a complia‚Ä¶

17/ ...But it's also a good example of why it's a good idea to check accounts for potential leads. Back in May that's what the Mail on Sunday did ‚Äî and it may be that it was their reporting that led the Charity Commission to investigate in the first place https://t.co/g4yTVEOOiE https://t.co/sXrLnbo2Nq

16/ So, a vague press release turned into a much more concrete and meaty story by simply using some basic techniques for finding information in company accounts. And a great way to make reporting stand out from all the other stories

15/ The reporter could have added further background by searching for the trustees/directors names on Companies House to add information about other companies they're involved in https://t.co/bkP9LrzLuh https://t.co/zcxdSS5kOw

14/ ...Well, "remuneration" is always a good place to look - also in the notes to the accounts - and that's where it comes from.
 (Related party transactions, at the end of the accounts, is also a good place to check) https://t.co/0900YI4t45
13/ What about the next paragraph in the story which describes payments to a trustee..? https://t.co/iRvYuDbTbF https://t.co/kHXOpjyoTA

12/ The clue is in the 'Notes' column: this points to extra detail in the 'notes to the accounts' section that comes next.
Note 6, then, on p11, gives more detail on those hefty fundraising costs - ¬£1.5m of them were on "event charges" https://t.co/MnYuL9sk2N

11/ Income and spending are normally the first set of numbers, here on p6: we can see that ¬£1.6m was spent on "raising funds" but just ¬£5,515 of the funds raised were spent on "charitable activities" - down from over ¬£300k the previous year. Can we find more details? https://t.co/GyMdBGBgSc
@markpack I've not tried that one so not sure, sorry. But thanks for drawing it to my attention!
10/ For the detail we need to head over to the 'Accounts and annual returns' page https://t.co/VqtXV5Pxdq and download the most recent accounts available. https://t.co/rN8qeawzg0

9/ ...Well, the Charity Commission does very usefully provide a breakdown of how much each charity spends on "charitable activities" on the charity overview page https://t.co/EEehtF33Dj ‚Äî but it's not that... https://t.co/ywjRKtqFLg

8/ ...but then we get to the more interesting detail from the accounts. It spent less than 1% of its income on "good causes". How does the reporter know this..? (Clue: it's not in the press release) https://t.co/LoImIGOPqV

7/ In this case, the reporter hasn't spotted what's happening - the Charity Commission has - and now they need to scramble to find some background to flesh out a very vague press release.
Some is basic context about what the charity has been doing lately, from news reports... https://t.co/NnG9yt6hTQ

6/ You can sign up for alerts on the Companies House website for new documents from companies - but annoyingly not on the Charity Commission. So try a tool like Visualping to provide email updates on when a webpage has changed (including late notices). https://t.co/1pNDOu1gsS

5/ The latest accounts are overdue by 179 days - late accounts are a good reason to check out earlier ones to see why that might be happening, and to make some calls to see if there are any concerns/activity etc. which might be newsworthy (but not defamatory) https://t.co/LiDHs0TONK

4/ You can search for a charity's accounts on the Charity Commission register - here's a search for Fashion For Relief https://t.co/uXlsI2OC9B - and here's the charity's page https://t.co/vLAcb7DI1X...
3/ ...But a reporter could have found some good story leads on the supermodel's charity much earlier if they'd been looking, as the details of the story show... https://t.co/fQSJpPLvQz

2/ First up: the story *lead* doesn't come from company accounts, it comes from a press release: https://t.co/l1HRz1glKM ‚Äî you can get email alerts about announcements from the Charity Commission here: https://t.co/BVcBbcYVto ...

üßµIt's time for another journey into the world of telling stories through company accounts - this time Naomi Campbell's fashion charity is under investigation! 
The story is here: https://t.co/iRvYuDbTbF But how did the reporter find the details..?

@Brummiecris I don‚Äôt read the screenshot you‚Äôve shared that way at all, but happy to accept that you do.

@Brummiecris And this: https://t.co/T8WcWaw8u8 - it‚Äôs the idea of a ‚Äúpublic conversation‚Äù where criticisms and concerns are aired and responses sought. If the plans are ‚Äúanti-car‚Äù then much of the criticism will be from car owners - but not all.

@Brummiecris Also what all the previous examples share is those holding power announcing a plan, and the newspaper giving a voice to criticism from below. That‚Äôs a key role it plays - holding power to account. For example https://t.co/jbRNkuuLLU

@Brummiecris One of the big challenges I explore with data journalism students is how to find something newsworthy in slow-moving background phenomena like global heating, years of life lost to air pollution etc. It‚Äôs harder, which is why you see less of it.

@Brummiecris https://t.co/dgaAyCR9CS
But also all those examples are not ‚Äúnews‚Äù in the sense that they happens every year. If the figures shot up they would be though.
@Brummiecris I might be wrong of course, but I think the appearance of bias is more easily explained.

@Brummiecris The alternative would read like a PR puff piece: ‚ÄúBus gates to benefit more people‚Äù. There‚Äôs a bias but it‚Äôs not anti-car, it‚Äôs just generally news orgs have always focused more on bad news and conflict for various reasons

@Brummiecris Looking at those examples it seems that they‚Äôve chosen to focus on reaction to the new information, which is a common news value (as is negativity). That doesn‚Äôt strike me as evidence of a pro-car bias, just that bad news tends to get attention

...Now version 3: narrow down to public data releases specifically and shifting the first stage to <0 hours to highlight the preparation (thanks @davidottewell & @stephengrey) #ddj https://t.co/oLCb6wdtl7

@davidottewell @craigmcginty @ColinGeorgeBBC Yes, this all came from a question where I suspected they were defining something as reactive/proactive depending on the dataset so I wanted to illustrate how the same dataset can lead to both types of story. But it does end up omitting other dimensions of proactivity
Interpreting Data: Tips to Make Sure You Know How to Read the Numbers https://t.co/QL8prLorKB via @gijn

@davidottewell @craigmcginty @ColinGeorgeBBC Yes, I wonder whether to title the first stage <0 hours and make it more about 'before the release' to emphasise that many of these stories don't just start when the data is published.
@videojournalist @BarnieChoudhury Thanks Robb, will add that to the list of proactive sources in v2 (now wondering if I need a lifecycle for each type, e.g. FOI needs a long lead-in, etc.)

@StephenGrey @craigmcginty @ColinGeorgeBBC I would have put that in the initial 'reactive' phase? Although I can also see a case for potential 'bad data' stories in the 'move it on' phrase (e.g. "Concerns raised over 'flawed' homelessness figures")

30/ There are plenty more stories you can get from company accounts - here are just 9 ideas https://t.co/WcDQ3G9ire #bcujournos

29/ (Thanks to @FraserJopp for pointing out that the highest paid director amounts from year to year might not be a 'raise' because the director may have changed in that time - so use phrases like "the amount paid to the highest paid director rose by X%") https://t.co/9f9jSZCt2Q
@FraserJopp Good point - will add that in.

28/ And this is all from just ONE article. How did @jimwaterson get the idea? It may be as simple as setting up an alert for companies of interest: create a (free) account on Companies House & you can 'follow' any company to get free email alerts when they post a new filing https://t.co/Y8MRIiHm4N

27/ ...Of course, now you've got his name and month of birth you can look at what other companies he owns, not just in the UK but, using @opencorporates, in other jurisdictions too https://t.co/W9blIhcvHv

@jimwaterson Nope. Such a great article in terms of using so many different parts of the system, which is why it's such a great example to teach from. Tempted to do a network diagram of their corporate network as a bonus!

26/ ...A *quicker* way of seeing when the business was bought is to look under the People tab, and switching to the Persons with significant control sub-section, which also says when the notification was made https://t.co/noZzuDQJji https://t.co/BvPfYXg8ek

25/ ...There's a final par on the business being sold a couple years ago. Again this can be found in the filing history of the company and the last notification of a person with significant control, in October 2018 BUT... https://t.co/QuDPygcZcl

24/ ...The balance sheet also shows the "shareholders‚Äô funds" - described by Investopedia as "the amount that would be returned to shareholders if all a company's assets were liquidated and all its debts repaid‚Äù https://t.co/Zb7PKnN2Yd - as being in negative figures https://t.co/t2AtweTfws
23/ ...What we *can* see, though, is the balance sheet of what it owns and owes. The company only had ¬£4,468 in the bank and its assets had dropped by 74%... https://t.co/CVACUhwUWz

22/ Those are ‚Äòexemption' accounts, meaning that they don't include details on how much money was coming into the business ‚Äî but we can tell that the company wasn't doing enough business - "more than ¬£10.2 million" - to be required to publish that... https://t.co/BIQZbCF6Sj

21/ We can investigate whether this company was worth ¬£23m by seeing how much business the company was doing before it was bought. Check which accounts cover a period before the acquisition - they are likely to have been published *after*... https://t.co/LyFSxFYqha
#bcujournos https://t.co/9CONoaFcMm

20/ ...Now @jimwaterson returns to the purchase of that company owned by the founders. Was it worth ¬£23m? To find out we can dig into the accounts of that company https://t.co/LyFSxFYqha - this also allows us to establish who controlled the company and when it was bought... https://t.co/r7w1pcjDcD

19/ ...To map the family network further you could click on each director‚Äôs name to see what other directorships they hold/have held, and search for their name - directors often have multiple entries https://t.co/DQCkYfrWir https://t.co/0aBU3wZeQ4

18/ ...her brother Tom, however, isn‚Äôt listed here. Instead knowledge of his role comes from background research, such as this BuzzFeed article which also provides that information on the increase in signups after a Beyonce mention https://t.co/vdDwhNZ5Xu

17/ Family connections! @jimwaterson next tells us about the sister who was a former director. This paragraph draws on information you can find on Companies House by looking at the People tab for the company... https://t.co/b0OzKB8Jgd #bcujournos https://t.co/mz7E9iTKZR

16/ The info on profit is on page 1 too but can be found in the cash flow statement if it's not. Cash held is in the balance statement.
Translating the jargon is important: "cash balances" in the accounts is translated to "held in cash" for the reader.
#bcujournos https://t.co/AIIJW2qtir

15/ More background in the next paragraph is also taken from the first page of the company's accounts. This is translated into simpler language (‚Äúfans signing on‚Äù becomes ‚Äúcustomers‚Äù) 
#bcujournos https://t.co/Cdiy1fZs0Z

14/ Company accounts can also be useful for context - a brief paragraph of the relative success of this company can be based on checking the accounts of "long-established mainstream British media companies" to see if their growth is similar (on revenue, profit etc) #bcujournos https://t.co/JGACu0VRVF

13/ There's more to come on that ¬£23m - but first, some interesting detail on "illegal underage material" and videos related to trafficking. This comes from the ‚ÄòPrincipal Risks and Uncertainties‚Äô section at the front of a company's accounts - often a good source of stories https://t.co/gwjEPa4V9s

12/ But how does @jimwaterson know the company that was bought by Fenix for ¬£23m is connected with the founders? For this you need to search for more information on that company, and look at the directors section: https://t.co/5FTw9poCj9

11/ What about those tens of millions of pounds extracted? This detail is in another note - 21 - on Events after the reporting date. This type of note details anything important that happened after the financial year being reported on. https://t.co/1qSCtTo9rC
10/ Next up: "and it paid ¬£20m in dividends to its backers." This is also in the notes to the accounts. #bcujournos https://t.co/pI5E9D1SwI

9/ You can also work out how big an increase a director has had ‚Äî in this case it's a 760% pay rise: divide the increase of ¬£1,735,000 by the previous year's pay of ¬£228,000 to work this out (times the result by 100 to get the figure as a percentage change)

8/ Director pay normally comes in the notes to the accounts - in this case note 7 relating to Directors‚Äô remuneration. Look for the 'highest paid director' as a separate line to directors overall. #bcujournos https://t.co/67JOFOAcM4

7/ Next up: director pay. This is often compared with workers' pay - but in this case most of the 'workers' aren't directly employed, so instead the juxtaposition is with the claims that it makes about payments to 'creators' https://t.co/AM7v8UdnUa

6/ ...but if it hadn‚Äôt been there, you could also have found it in the first line of the statement of income, normally found after all the initial waffle in a set of accounts (it comes on p9) üí∞üí∞üí∞ https://t.co/4PA0A4YYJt

5/ With that carrot dangled, we establish some context: business is booming ‚Äî a 615% increase in the year up to November 2020 (the period that the accounts cover) to ¬£1.7bn. That's information from the "strategic report" on page 1... https://t.co/UbJow6ytwr

4/ The story starts by reporting that the founders "extracted tens of millions of pounds from its parent company in the last year". I'll come on to how that's established - but note re. libel that company accounts come under qualified privilege https://t.co/c6xfKC9H42 https://t.co/jThxa3jENK

3/ Search for the company on Companies House https://t.co/8MHsxpG0wi - the About page information on the director and address can be used to confirm that you have the right company https://t.co/S8iSzQts3J

2/ First, you need to locate the company behind OnlyFans. It's not called OnlyFans so you can either Google it, or look for an 'About' section on the site that leads you to the company - in this case, Fenix International Limited https://t.co/qc2E1fFJiz

#bcujournos ...Don't be afraid to say "If you can't help me, do you know of any other organisations or anyone that might be able to assist in some way?" @Paul_SDU advises. "And hopefully they'll be willing to oblige."

"An organisation might say I can't help you [source a case study] but can put you in touch with a group who can," says @Paul_SDU "And sometimes you need to prepare yourself to be passed between 4 different people first before you get to where you want to be." #bcujournos

#bcujournos "You have a reputation [of the organisation] to uphold," when it comes to approaching potential sources, @Paul_SDU points out. But other news organisations might have a different reputation and that might change how you approach people differently

#bcujournos Once you're talking to someone, @Paul_SDU says, "it's probably then that you can say 'I'd like to do a fuller interview on the record, if you maybe want a day to think about it and then I'll give you a call tomorrow and see how you feel'..."

#bcujournos "...Explain who you are first," says @Paul_SDU. "Say I'm a journalist working on this, I'd love to hear your story. Even if it's only for background. Don't discount having chats with people, even if you're not going to interview them formally it's going to inform you"

#bcujournos When sending messages to potential case studies @Paul_SDU emphasises always being sensitive: "The last thing you want to be is really terse and say 'Hi I'm doing a story on this can you give me a call please?' No one's going to do that..."
@YazzieSpeaks @mediaghosts @Paul_SDU @scholarCHIPS Thanks!
RT @mediaghosts: @paulbradshaw @Paul_SDU Hey @paulbradshaw , Children of Incarcerated Parents CHIPS, provides coaching to young people. @Ya‚Ä¶

"...You can start really broad and Google who has spoken to the media before. If they've done it before they may be good to speak to. You do lose that exclusivity a little, but then you also in slightly safer territory because you know they're aware of what to expect" #bcujournos

"My method is to start really broad [when finding case studies]," says @Paul_SDU. "Go to charities, campaign groups. The smaller the better. You're going to have a lot more personal chat, and you're less likely to get routed through the press office." #bcujournos

"A case study is like finding a needle in a haystack to begin with," says @Paul_SDU. "But try looking for someone who works with the type of person you're looking for, or a trade body. Sometimes we just have to ask 'the person who knows'." #bcujournos

"Part of this story really was that [prisons'] communication was so bad," says @Paul_SDU. "In many cases they didn't let any of the families know that they'd reopened the visiting halls again" #ddj #bcujournos https://t.co/UQ2CDTWT3v

We scraped official prison webpage changelogs to see when visiting was allowed, + scraped their Twitter accounts as a second source - but they didn't always tally, so a lot of manual checking and follow-ups were needed to complete the picture. An FOI request was refused.

RT @petewhite: Good points in this thread. Other sloppy writing‚Äî"Do not be seduced by the informality of tone and language on social media.‚Ä¶
@bigaljnr To be fair it doesn't suggesting giving equal weighting - only reflecting all viewpoints. But that "due" bit (i.e. reflecting that some aren't true!) is the key omission.
...and @kellyfincham points out the difficulty of putting the BBC guidelines into industry context https://t.co/LsdcoR7eOq - research by @MichOpgenhaffen helps: https://t.co/LMalrZ8tU9

Extra notes on the thread about the BBC guidelines on social media use: good point about hashtags from @adambanksdotcom: they can be used as a distribution method, not just to express 'something I support' (and in other ways too) https://t.co/GUSs9Z5bfv

20/ ü§¶Ironically the use of "virtue signalling" in the BBC guidance serves as a perfect example of the sloppiness of writing that the guidance itself advises against. 
The result? It's undermined perceptions of the BBC's impartiality. 
Very meta. https://t.co/P8b4ITYmiH

19/ ...Now we come to the VIRTUE SIGNALLING: 
‚ÄúAvoid ‚Äòvirtue signalling‚Äô ‚Äì retweets, likes or joining online campaigns to indicate a personal view‚Äù 
The most curious part of this is the use of ‚Äòvirtue signalling‚Äô ‚Äî there‚Äôs no need to use this loaded term. It's a waste of 2 words

‚ìµ‚ìº/ Another big one: ‚ÄúUse of emojis can ‚Äì accidentally, or deliberately ‚Äì undercut an otherwise impartial post.‚Äù 
Misinterpreted as an ‚õîÔ∏è-emoji guideline, it does not say *not* to use emoji: it's simply advising understanding how to use them effectively and accurately. https://t.co/YjJ0AZ6dtp

17/ One worrying theme in the BBC guidelines relates to factchecking/debunking: 

‚ÄúDo be careful with rebuttals ‚Äì they can feed conflict.‚Äù 

Should the desire to avoid conflict override the need to tell the truth? It's not a simple answer: https://t.co/anin5lAMWI
16/ ...Ditto warnings about tweets requiring "careful thought and editorial discipline.‚Äù and ‚Äúthinking about the language you are using or how it could be perceived.‚Äù https://t.co/VwQiDSpnmF

15/ For an example of the sort of sloppy social writing relevant to that guideline, look at tweets during the 2019 election about an "assault" on a political adviser. Many failed to accurately communicate that these were claims and hadn't been confirmed https://t.co/VnfHAbHSxu
RT @adambanksdotcom: Like "likes", hashtags serve a variety of purposes and don't imply approval. The assumption here seems to be that usin‚Ä¶

14/ Especially welcome are a couple of sections that emphasise the importance of clear writing and attribution on social ‚Äî broadcast journalists have too often been guilty of sloppy writing on this front. I teach my MA students at @BCUJournalism explicitly about this issue https://t.co/3H8GqkAIiD

13/ A couple of sections of the BBC guidance acknowledge the dangers of echo chambers and how our feeds are algorithmically filtered. In fact, it should probably go further in urging reporters to seek out different voices. https://t.co/zPv8S9RJRY

12/ The BBC guidance recommends treating private groups as public ‚Äî again, good advice. There is no such thing as a private group or personal account on social media when you are a journalist. https://t.co/TmZHNaBjrN

11/ ...Well, later it does say ‚ÄúDo not support campaigns, (eg. by using hashtags) no matter how apparently worthy the cause or how much their message appears to be accepted or uncontroversial.‚Äù 
The difference? A hashtag can be a number of things, including campaigns. https://t.co/XZE2VVzQo8

10/ ...Likewise, the BBC guidance doesn‚Äôt *stop* people using hashtags/liking/sharing. 
It only recommends that journalists ‚Äúthink about what your likes, shares, retweets, use of hashtags and who you follow say about you, your personal prejudices and opinions.‚Äù 
Or does it? https://t.co/G0FBknYeL6

9/ The BBC guidance to ‚Äúassume anything you say or post will be viewed critically‚Äù *doesn‚Äôt* say the employee should *not* tweet ‚Äî this is basically another way of saying "consider the audience" and is sound advice. https://t.co/kx17nuCljP

8/ There's a recognitiion of the rising abuse faced by journalists in ‚ÄúDo always treat others with respect, even in the face of abuse‚Äù ‚Äî but this offers little support for the journalists facing such abuse. https://t.co/UvOxkkLnIk

7/ ...Now we come to a big one: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt criticise your colleagues in public.‚Äù It comes as a straight command with no justification, no room for interpretation, and no caveats. Criticism is often justified, and can be constructive. If any line was ill-judged, this is it. https://t.co/x83ApLlZdU
RT @PeterKGeoghegan: Not for second saying they're not significant issues, but struck by how much debate there is about Jeremy Corbyn and B‚Ä¶

6/ ...This approach is mirrored later on with ‚Äúthere is no difference between how a personal and an ‚Äòofficial‚Äô account is perceived on social media‚Äù. 
What evidence is there for this? And shouldn‚Äôt more be done to correct that perception (it is, after all, wrong)? https://t.co/pPJS7TCrvK

5/ ...Instead or focusing on appearances and accepting others‚Äô perceptions as fact, why not work on recommending journalists are more transparent about how they ensure impartiality in their *methods* (to debunk those perceptions)

4/ It‚Äôs üòî to see a US-style approach adopted of being concerned with how journalists *appear* rather than what they *do* with ‚Äúan obligation to ensure that the BBC‚Äôs editorial decisions are not perceived to be influenced by any personal interest or bias.‚Äù

3/ ...There is no mention of ‚Äúdue impartiality‚Äù and it‚Äôs worth highlighting that this guidance should be combined with BBC guidance on impartiality https://t.co/eYZYngF5Uk https://t.co/DOAyrZO9Ho

2/ The guidance makes a good point for the need to stay out of an increasingly polarised environment, but then it makes the mistake of ambiguously describing impartiality as ‚Äúreflecting all viewpoints‚Äù... https://t.co/OFAHldPQGI
Are the BBC‚Äôs new social media guidelines as draconian as has been reported? Looking at the actual guidelines it isn‚Äôt quite so clear cut. THREAD! https://t.co/kx17nuCljP https://t.co/LmjAFlx9XZ

...The research ends by noting that no journalists addressed the evasive shifts by the PM - and including examples of how journalists might do that: https://t.co/qfLT2kSYmU

@eldiablo0786 @Bravo1Niner @SandwellSkidder @Jim5875 The Birmingham Mail did/does - In Your Area. Although I think a lot of the blogs stopped publishing and it developed into something slightly different?

@AliJaneMoore @birmingham_live I do, seems to just make it worse.
@LukeBeardsworth @lylebignon @birmingham_live Fantastic. Hadn‚Äôt thought of that - forgot it even existed!

@SandwellSkidder Agreed - there's a myth about journalism that doesn't really reflect the much more prosaic reality. Vast majority of journalism is routine, transmitting functional information to wider audiences, and not even news (e.g. magazines). But the ¬£ from that supports the exceptions

@Bravo1Niner @SandwellSkidder @Jim5875 @eldiablo0786 A lot of news is now shared between papers in the Reach group so national stories like that tend to be republished from the Mirror in order to try to sell more advertising at a local level, which can then (in theory) pay local reporters to cover more stories locally.

@SandwellSkidder Like any job, most journalists don't start out being amazing. They get better as they gain experience, contacts + knowledge. It takes years to get them to the position where they can regularly do investigative work. Sack them & you reset the clock + reduce the pipeline

@SandwellSkidder This is why so many hyperlocal websites & independent & citizen journalists do so many investigations - they don't have to fill X space & they're not paid to do it. At the same time, we can't expect them to do it forever, or comprehensively.

@SandwellSkidder There's a confusion between what reporters *should* be (investigative, proactive) + what most actually *can* be most of the time because of time & resource limitations (simple story about a statement = practical; investigation without guaranteed story = not)

@SandwellSkidder So a reporter who has 30 minutes to research and write a story (for example) will not be able to leave their desk. A reporter in an organisation with 2x reporters will have (all else being equal) 2x the time to report, and so on.

@SandwellSkidder I think that's what people misunderstand. Their job, strictly speaking, is to fill a certain amount of pages/websites/airtime. They have a certain amount of time to do the research/recording + writing/editing to fill that. The results reflect the time they have for each story

@cgeary44 @KirmanLorna @jburnmurdoch For example some research last year found that people with strong beliefs refused to believe Trump's own staff when presented with their statements admitting that he had lied about inauguration crowd size (same effect, but not media or lack of trust)

@cgeary44 @KirmanLorna @jburnmurdoch The next step (and I think some research has already looked at this) is what role trust in the media plays in that process. There's a lot we don't know about this (and a lot of conclusions to easily jump to/confirmation bias) and it's important to emphasise that

@cgeary44 @KirmanLorna @jburnmurdoch If that was the case then the numbers not believing a factcheck would be the same for all groups of audiences ‚Äî the research is looking at that specific variable (whether being actively misinformed makes someone less likely to believe a factcheck).
@tom_e_white is this your project? https://t.co/CjGslp9VWz - it's using your data but wasn't sure if it was you?

@cgeary44 @KirmanLorna @jburnmurdoch The whole point of the research is that 'just giving people the facts' doesn't work (and journalists have operated on the assumption that it would). People will reject the facts if it contradicts their deeply-held views (the "backfire effect")

@GuyFawkesRight @PeterKGeoghegan Human nature is most to blame, if you read the research (the "backfire effect"). Once people settle on an opinion they resist information that contradicts it, regardless of what journalist/publication it comes from.
@ClaireJWilde @JodyyDC @thomasforth Definitely. There's a big vacuum in data which people are now understandably trying to fill.

@adambanksdotcom What I find fascinating about applying narrative theory is that even apparently v different structures like inverted pyramid vs longform vs first person features vs movies actually share similar structures, e.g. a coda at the end

@adambanksdotcom Also, there's often an element of students assuming that they 'know' how to use the platform because they're digitally native, whereas in fact they know how to use it personally but using it professionally is a whole different set of practices

@adambanksdotcom Yes - and actually that module covers both, often in the same class: so we might talk about narrative structures in the inverted pyramid and then apply the same concepts to liveblogs, Snapchat stories, social video, podcasts etc.

@adambanksdotcom And new platforms are a great way to explore those concepts because they're not yet settled, so you can look at why people are making editorial decisions beyond mere conventional practice, and what effects/success they have ‚Äî then students can experiment+reflect themselves

@adambanksdotcom Snapchat was a massive eye-opener for me: when I was trying to understand it I realised I was drawing on principles of composition, sequence and temporality in narrative, sound design, semiotics ‚Äî and looking back at 19thC cinema experiments!
@EastEndEnquirer Patches are tricky ‚Äî they can be useful as a pedagogical device and in focusing students on building contacts/knowledge from scratch, but also have the weaknesses you identify.

@adambanksdotcom I agree about deep foundations/principles ‚Äî I teach a module about new formats which draws on a range of traditional narrative conceptual frameworks, but my experience of students coming from traditional universities is that they were taught as if change didn't exist

I suspect this reflects the fact that traditional unis (which rank more highly overall) systemically value theory over practice and tend to be quite conservative. So it's hardly surprising ‚Äî but I wonder how many students/parents realise this https://t.co/WSdQwt5XQD

@digidickinson Agree. It's an odd place to start but I imagine many students/parents have the same naive approach ("go to a good university" rather than "do a good course") so it's interesting from that point of view

Research: "Journalism and Communication Degrees of the best ranked universities... tend to focus mainly on theoretical courses [and] are not ready to adapt to structural changes that communication and the profession have undergone in recent years." https://t.co/EGhlcutBne

5/ The testing figures have now become so skewed by surveillance testing and dominated by sent tests that the aggregate figures are not very useful, but without any indication of how 'people tested' is arrived at, that becomes hard to understand, as the stats regulator as noted https://t.co/DpvPzSED9W

@leguape Not sure how they could count people and tests on different days (for example sent tests are counted on day sent, lab tests are counted on day sample is tested) - nothing in https://t.co/rlHZnjnCmG about people being counted at different point to tests

4/ Surveillance testing figures, as far as I understand it, do not contribute to the 'people tested' figures because they are anonymised, so can we discount those? The language is a little ambiguous, however: https://t.co/O7D7EnK0r4

3/ ...But on some days, the number of people tested is *more* than the total of tests done under in-person routes (13th May for example: 60,000 in-person tests but 71,000 people tested). So it can't be just that.

2/ But there's a big problem with that 'people tested' figure: it's not clear how a person is counted as tested. For example: yesterday 80,000 tests were sent out but the figure for 'people tested' was much lower: 60,000. We might hypothesise they're not including those - BUT...
